summary: This document appears to be a message or email discussing the ongoing case against Jean-Luc Brunel in France and his connection to Jeffrey Epstein. It alleges that Brunel's modeling agencies, funded by Epstein, were used to recruit and traffic victims internationally, and expresses concern that these agencies continue to operate under new ownership despite the deaths of Epstein and Brunel. The author urges a connection between the recipient and Anne Claire Le Jeune, Brunel's lawyer, to discuss these matters.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.role: Modeling agency owner, accused associate of Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the document. He is described as having modeling agencies funded by Epstein that were used to recruit and traffic victims internationally. The case against him in France is noted as ongoing.

persons.name: Anne Claire Le Jeune
persons.context: Identified as Brunel's lawyer (Maitre/AVOCAT). The author suggests connecting the recipient with her to discuss matters related to Brunel and justice for his victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the funder of Jean-Luc Brunel's modeling agencies, which were allegedly used as fronts for international sex trafficking.

connections.description: Epstein funded Brunel's modeling agencies, which were allegedly used to traffic victims.
Le Jeune is identified as Brunel's lawyer (avocat).
Brunel's former bookkeeper provided a sworn statement in 2010 confirming the use of his agencies for trafficking.

events.title: Bookkeeper's Sworn Statement
events.description: Brunel's former bookkeeper provided a sworn statement confirming his modeling agencies were used to traffic victims for Epstein.

events.title: Sale of Epstein's Paris Apartment
events.description: A French company owned by Epstein's estate (JEP) completed a transaction to sell Epstein's old Paris apartment to an entity named Tuchev.

events.title: Guardian Article Publication
events.description: The Guardian published an article detailing abuse allegations against Jean-Luc Brunel by six women, linking him to Epstein.

keyFacts: Jean-Luc Brunel's modeling agencies (Karin Models, MC2) were allegedly funded by Jeffrey Epstein and used as fronts to recruit and traffic victims internationally.
Despite the deaths of Epstein and Brunel, the document claims these modeling agencies continue to operate under new ownership, raising concerns that trafficking may still be occurring.
A 2010 sworn statement from Brunel's former bookkeeper confirmed the agencies' role in trafficking for Epstein.
The document questions why Brunel's agencies were never thoroughly investigated or shut down, instead being sold to new owners.
The author urges a connection between the recipient and Brunel's lawyer, Anne Claire Le Jeune, to discuss pursuing justice for Brunel's victims.
